title: When the chips are down, revenue goes down too
text:
Good evening

Today's European Commission survey showing more than half of EU manufacturers suffering shortages of material and equipment follows a week of corporate warnings about supply chain problems, and in particular the shortfall in semiconductors.

The surge in demand for chips has contributed to soaring inflation in the US and Europe. Wider supply constraints were also cited this morning as a reason for Germany's economy shrinking in the final quarter of last year.

The chip shortage has been a recurrent theme in the current earnings season. Apple, which reported yesterday, is one of the few big companies that seems to have navigated around the problem, with iPad sales being the only key segment affected, although supply chain problems still cost the company more than $6bn in fourth-quarter revenues.

GE on Tuesday said shortages of semiconductors were a key factor in falling revenues, the same day as a report from the US commerce department found that demand for chips from American manufacturers had surged 17 per cent between 2019 and 2021, leaving companies with just five days' worth of supplies instead of the pre-pandemic norm of 40.

Tesla on Wednesday warned of the effect of supply chain hold-ups on this year's results, even as it reported a record net profit of $2.3bn in the fourth quarter of last year.

The chip crisis is also hitting the car industry across the Atlantic. New industry data this week showed UK car production fell 6.7 per cent last year from 2020 to leave it a third lower than pre-pandemic levels.

For companies such as Samsung however, times are good. The world's biggest producer of computer chips and smartphones yesterday reported its highest fourth-quarter operating profit in four years.

Innovation editor John Thornhill describes the hunt for semiconductors as our era's industrial ‘Great Game' as the likes of Samsung, Taiwan Semiconductor and Intel, which last week announced it was spending $20bn on two chip factories in Ohio, ramp up investment.

Cristiano Amon, chief executive of US chip designer Qualcomm, has likened the tech rivalry to gladiatorial combat in ancient Rome. “You go in, you prepare, you go to the Colosseum. If you win, all that you have accomplished is the right to go to the Colosseum one more time,” he told the FT.

Latest news

  • The US and EU pledged to work together to guarantee energy supplies to Europe if an attack on Ukraine affected the supply of Russian gas

  • Argentina agreed a deal with the IMF to restructure a $57bn bailout package

  • The UK said it would start giving Pfizer's Covid-19 pill to vulnerable people next month (Reuters)

For up-to-the-minute news updates, visit our live blog

Need to know: the economy

US labour costs rose sharply in the fourth quarter while separate data today showed the Federal Reserve's preferred measure of inflation increased 4.9 per cent in December from the year before, giving extra impetus to the central bank's attempts to speed up the withdrawal of its pandemic stimulus programme. Fed chair Jay Powell on Wednesday signalled a tougher stance, triggering a stock market sell-off.

Data yesterday showed US economic growth hitting a better than expected 6.9 per cent at the end of the year before Omicron struck.

Germany's economy shrank 0.7 per cent in the final quarter of last year as consumer spending fell and supply constraints hit manufacturing. In contrast, France grew by 0.7 per cent, taking the increase for the year to seven per cent, the fastest expansion for 52 years and good news for President Emmanuel Macron's re-election prospects.

Latest for the UK and Europe

The UK government is coming under increasing pressure to postpone the forthcoming rise in national insurance to ease the growing cost of living crisis, a problem highlighted by a debate over how inflation affects low-income families. A parliamentary report said chancellor Rishi Sunak's October Budget helped drive up inflation, which is also pushing more British companies towards insolvency.

The Turkish lira has stabilised after government interventions — described by one consultant as “electroshock therapy” — including new government-backed savings schemes and a multibillion-dollar intervention by the central bank.

Global latest

A Japanese business group warned that the country's strict border restrictions could deter foreign investment and ruin Tokyo's attempt to compete as a global financial centre. The government reimposed the measures in late November and they are set to remain in place until at least the end of February. Japan this week reported record numbers of new infections.

South Africa raised interest rates again to reach 4 per cent in response to rising inflation. The country's central bank also warned that investors could start pulling money out of emerging markets if faster rate rises in the US and other major economies made investing at home more attractive.

Need to know: business

Chevron became the latest oil major to report benefits from surging crude and natural gas prices. Fourth-quarter net income was $5.1bn, up from a $665m loss in the same period a year earlier. Brent crude passed $90 a barrel this week for the first time since 2014.

LVMH, owner of brands such as Moët and Louis Vuitton, reported new records for profits and sales thanks to strong demand in the US and China. Companies editor Tom Braithwaite ponders the company's unstoppable rise: “We have become accustomed to so much weirdness in the past two years that it is worth underlining: the current luxury boom is not normal,” he writes.

It's also a good time to be a management consultant in tech as companies shift more of their operations online. Read more in our special report and browse our fifth annual list of the UK consulting firms most recommended by clients and peers.

British Airways unveiled its post-pandemic strategy with a pledge to restore its reputation for premium service to differentiate it from its “no-frills” rivals. One of those, easyJet, said it was confident of a pick-up in summer ticket sales. US carrier Southwest was similarly optimistic on full-year profits for 2022 but predicted a loss for the first quarter thanks to Omicron and staff shortages.

Rising payroll costs and falling trading revenues meant profits at Deutsche Bank's investment banking business almost halved in the fourth quarter. Overall profits for the full year however quadrupled to €2.5bn, the highest level since 2011.

Science round up

Pandemic management: A study from Imperial College London raised concerns that rising infections among schoolchildren could spark a resurgence in Omicron infections in older people.

A study of data from a symptom tracker app on Monday suggested UK cases had risen 10 per cent over the previous week.

The Omicron subvariant BA. 2 is “likely more infectious” than the original, according to British scientists.

Denmark became the latest European country to lift almost all pandemic restrictions, following the UK, Ireland and the Netherlands.

Our Big Read examines the poor performance of US public health bodies and their failure to get Omicron under control.

Vaccines: UK data showed double vaccination cut the risk of long Covid by 40 per cent.

BioNTech/Pfizer started the first clinical trials of a specific Omicron vaccine. Moderna is also gearing up for Omicron-focused trials.

Treatments: US regulators said treatments from Regeneron and Eli Lilly were “highly unlikely” to work against Omicron.
